value.title: DAX Fridays! #41: LOOKUPVALUE with multiple columns
value.excerpt: In todays DAX Friday video, we will learn how to use the DAX Function called LOOKUPVALUE: Lookupvalue is very similar to excel's VLookup but there are some critical differences that you need to understand if you want to use it. We will have two scenarios,: Scenario 1: we will do a lookupvalue with two

value.title: DAX Fridays! #80: DATESBETWEEN
value.excerpt: In todays video we are going to cover the DAX function DATESBETWEEN.  DATESBETWEEN function allows you to calculate amounts between two dates you specify.   For example, if you want to calculate the sum of sales between two specific dates, this is the perfect function for you.  You can "hardcode" the

value.title: DAX Fridays! #9: RANKX DAX Function
value.excerpt: Learn how to use the DAX RANKX() function to arrange your data based on criteria that you specify. value.title: List dates between two dates in Power Query

value.title: Power BI vs Excel: When you should use each tool
value.excerpt: Which tool is best? Power BI or Excel?  Well, it depends on what you are trying to do. Both tools have unique strengths and limitations and in this video I will try to show both.  Hopefully after watching this video, you will have a better understanding of both tools and will know when to use which depending

value.title: Running totals in power query??? Yes, you can :)
value.excerpt: In today's video, I am going to show you how you can do running totals or cummulative totals in Power Query, but do this only if you have no way to do it using DAX. value.title: Forecasting in Power BI
value.excerpt: In this video, we will learn how we can forecast our data in Power BI. We will be discussing which visualization supports forecasting in Power BI.
